ANALYSTS AND DOCTORS TAKE A CLOSER LOOK AT IMPLANTED EYE LENSES 

  
 (ATTN: Calif., Kan., Texas)  (ART ADV: Two photos and a graphic are being sent to NYT graphic
clients. Non-subscribers can make individual purchase by calling
888-603-1036 or 888-346-9867.) 
(Duplication warning: Also moved in `f' category) 
(DW) 
 By DAVID J. MORROW   
 c.1999 N.Y. Times News Service   

   After wearing glasses for 31 years, Debrah Ward jumped at a
chance last May to give them up. Instead of receiving laser
surgery, an alternative to contact lenses and eyeglasses, Ms. Ward
had clear polymer arcs implanted in her near-sighted right eye.

   The arcs, known as Intacs, are an experimental treatment made by
Keravision, a tiny California company. The arcs, which can be
inserted during a 10-minute procedure in an ophthalmologist's
office, flatten the cornea to correct mild nearsightedness, or
myopia, a condition that affects some 22 million Americans.

   ``I never had vision this good,'' said Ms. Ward, a 38-year-old
accountant in Olathe, Kan., who took part in the Intacs clinical
trials. Her eyesight improved from 20/20 with glasses to 20/10 with
the implants. ``It's nothing short of amazing,'' she said. ``I've
gone around and told all my friends about it.''

   If the Food and Drug Administration, as expected, approves
Intacs this spring, it will be the first surgical corneal implant
for vision correction to be sold in the United States. At the same
time, companies like Bausch & Lomb, the contact lens giant, and
Staar Surgical, a small California concern, are racing to develop
other types of eye implants, technologies that are similar to
Intacs and essentially are permanent contact lenses.

   Still other developments are under way. Presby Corp., a tiny
biotechnology company in Dallas, is developing a plastic implant
that would eliminate the need for reading glasses and bifocal
lenses. Early clinical trials are set to begin in the United States
next month. All these products, which could be available in the
next several years, are aimed at grabbing a share of the $11
billion Americans now spend each year for glasses and contact
lenses.

   While doctors and analysts are leery of predicting how popular
vision-corrective implants may become _ they will cost as much as
$2,500 an eye and they involve surgery _ their development is a
result of the recognition that many graying baby boomers are eager
to spend lots of money to turn back the effects of time.

   The excitement last year over Viagra, Pfizer Inc.'s impotency
pill, showed that there was an increasing demand among middle-aged
Americans for medical treatments that make their lives easier and
more fulfilling.

   Americans increasingly are willing to undergo cosmetic surgery,
the kind of procedure needed to wear optical implants. Americans
had 697,000 cosmetic operations in 1996, the latest year that
statistics are available, according to the American Society of
Plastic and Reconstructive Surgeons _ a 71.6 percent increase from
1992.

   Thomas M. Loarie, Keravision's chief executive, says he expects
that many of his customers will be 38 to 42 years old, who have no
problem spending on cosmetic surgery.

   ``This age group has more income,'' he said. ``They are not
afraid of trying something new.''

   Many analysts also say that Americans may snap up implants
because they increasingly are becoming frustrated with contact
lenses. After expanding for years, the contact-lens market in the
United States is barely growing. The number of annual replacement
soft contact-lens wearers, who account for 36 percent of the
market, declined 7.9 percent last year. The only boom in the market
is for daily disposable soft contacts, sales of which increased 44
percent last year.

   ``Intacs should have a broad appeal,'' said Katherine
Martinelli, an analyst with S.G. Cowen Securities Corp. ``People
won't have to worry about cleaning or replacing them. One of the
keys is that the products are going to have to be able to work in
broad range of people.''

   But the potential seen in implants comes with a number of
caveats.

   Given the manufacturers' small size _ Keravision had only
$835,000 in sales last year _ analysts are worried that the
companies lack the resources to make their products best sellers.
Even after an FDA advisory panel recommended Intacs for approval
last month, shares of Keravision, which is based in Fremont,
Calif., continue to trade below their July 1995 initial offering
price of $13.50. The shares closed Wednesday at $12.0625 in Nasdaq
trading.

   Possible side effects and complications range from blurred
vision with Intacs to a slim risk of cataracts with the Staar
Surgical lens. The implants are expensive, costing some $5,000 for
surgery to both eyes. Only 2,000 people have Intacs worldwide,
leaving their long-term safety unclear.

   ``This is not a casual procedure,'' said Ken Taylor, a vice
president at Arthur D. Little, a corporate consulting and research
firm. ``Eyesight is very precious to people. They are going to have
to be confident about the procedure and the product before they
will have it.''

   So far, the implant technology has been received favorably by
doctors. Made of a clear polymer that is used to correct cataracts,
Intacs are two arcs that are inserted surgically in the periphery
of the cornea. The arcs flatten the cornea to correct vision
primarily between 20/40 and 20/300, a treatment that could be used
by nearly one-third of the 70 million Americans who suffer from
myopia. The surgery takes about 10 minutes and requires a local
anesthesia administered through eyedrops.

   Insertion of Staar Surgical's intraocular contact lens, made of
a bendable polymer, takes about 20 minutes. Like Intacs, the lens
can be inserted in a ophthalmologist's office under local
anesthesia, but the procedure is slightly more invasive. The
contact lens fits just over the eye's natural lens behind the iris.

   Though several years away from market, Bausch & Lomb is
developing a lens that fits in front of the iris, a position that
doctors believe should reduce the risk of cataracts. The device has
two thin Z-shaped arms with tiny foot plates to help hold it in
place.

   Doctors say there is a slightly greater risk of infection from
the lens procedures, but their uses are far broader. Intacs
primarily correct mild nearsightedness, while the implanted lenses
have proved effective in early clinical trials as a remedy for a
greater range of myopia and farsightedness. With both procedures,
the implants can be easily removed. In the Intacs clinical trials,
when the lenses were removed, the patient's eyesight went back to
its uncorrected vision in most cases.

   Melanie Yourdon, a 30-year-old registered nurse near Kansas
City, Kan., had Intacs implanted in her left eye two years ago as
part of the trial. She became frustrated when she realized that her
vision was not 20/20. When her doctor looked at her incision, he
realized that it had not healed properly. It took him 10 minutes to
remove the Intacs implant.

   ``My incision healed once the ring was out,'' said Ms. Yourdon,
who has worn Intacs in her right eye since 1994. ``My vision went
back to what it was before, and I decided to have a laser
procedure. Now I see fine. The only thing is that when you go into
corrective eye surgery, you want to know that you'll have perfect
vision when you come out of it.''

   (MORE)   

   Of the 410 people who were evaluated after a year in the Intacs
clinical trials, 98 percent achieved 20/40 vision or better, while
78 percent attained vision that was 20/20 or better. Especially
noteworthy was that 56 percent achieved 20/16 vision or better.
Even though the data were not conclusive enough for the FDA
advisory panel to allow Keravision to state that Intacs provided
better vision, the results still caught doctors' attention.

   ``Getting better eyesight is a bonus with the rings,'' said Dr.
R. Doyle Stulting, a professor of ophthalmology at Emory University
in Atlanta who participated in the Intacs clinical trials.
``There's no guarantee that the rings will give you vision that is
better than what you had before with contacts or glasses. But when
people discover that there's something better out there, in this
case better than 20/20 vision, they'll want to have it.''

   Staar Surgical also reported excellent results in early trials
of its lens. In the trials' first phase, 9 of 10 patients who had
been legally blind without glasses achieved 20/20 vision or better
after receiving an implanted lens. The company began the third
phase of the trials last fall on some 300 patients.

   But not all wearers of such implants may be thrilled with the
devices. Given the cost of the procedure, side effects, while
minor, may prove a deterrent. Roughly 4.8 percent of the people in
the third phase of the Intacs clinical studies experienced
difficulty with night vision, while 2.9 percent reported blurry
vision. Other side effects included seeing double images, glare,
halos and fluctuating distance vision.

   The Staar Surgical lens caused no notable side effects during
its early clinical trials. John R. Wolf, Staar Surgical's chairman,
acknowledges that there is a slim chance that the lenses may cause
cataracts as a complication from poorly performed surgery. A
spokeswoman for Staar Surgical, which is based in Monrovia, Calif.,
said that there had been fewer than 10 reported cases of cateracts
in the 7,000 lenses that had been installed worldwide so far.

   ``With the Staar lens, since it tucked underneath the iris, the
patient is less likely to experience glare and halos,'' said Dr.
Sheri L. Rowen, director of the eye and cosmetic center at Mercy
Medical Center in Baltimore. ``But you have to be gentle installing
it. You don't want to move the lens around.''

   Further reducing the allure of implants, patients still may need
glasses following the procedure. ``Eventually, 100 percent of all
people need reading glasses,'' said Dr. Penny A. Asbell, a
professor of opthamology at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine in
Manhattan who participated in the Intacs clinical trials. ``A
nearsighted person who gets Intacs will also need them. There's no
surgical procedure yet that can change that.''

   Doctors also share analysts' concerns about the small size of
Staar Surgical and Keravision, the leading implant companies. Staar
Surgical had sales last year of some $54.5 million compared with
Bausch & Lomb's $2.36 billion in sales and Johnson & Johnson's
$23.6 billion. Keravision's finances are especially precarious. The
company, which has yet to post a profit in its 13-year history,
gets the majority of its financing from bond and stock offerings.

   Given the size of Staar Surgical and Keravision, analysts have
speculated that either company could be acquired by a contact lens
giant, like Johnson & Johnson or Bausch & Lomb. Several analysts
and doctors said they would applaud such a deal.

   ``The big question here really is execution,'' Ms. Martinelli,
the Cowen Securities analyst, said. ``It's great technology, hands
down. But great technology does not always mean great sales.''
